user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of find_entry_by_userinfo:
```c
static struct UserEntry *
find_entry_by_userinfo (const struct MHD_DigestAuthUsernameInfo *username_info)
{
  if (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_STANDARD <= username_info->uname_type)
    return find_entry_by_username (username_info->username);

  if (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_USERHASH == username_info->uname_type)
    return find_entry_by_userhash (username_info->algo3,
                                   username_info->userhash_bin,
                                   username_info->userhash_hex_len / 2);

  return NULL; /* Should be unreachable as all cases are covered before */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
    return find_entry_by_username (username_info->username);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown fragment: find_entry_by_userinfo simply calls find_entry_by_username and there is no evidence here of a call back. This only violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 if there is a recursion cycle elsewhere — for example, if find_entry_by_username were implemented to call find_entry_by_userinfo (directly) or if find_entry_by_username calls funcA which calls funcB which calls find_entry_by_userinfo (indirect cycle).
